_prev_prog_3.MD_OtherType: Hazmat Foam System, Firefighting foam System, Mineral Oil Dump System

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Equistar Chemicals, LP, Edison Site, has a Risk Management Program which meets the requirements of OSHA PSM, EPA RMP, and Program 3 NJ TCPA Risk Management Program. The Site Quality and Environmental management systems are certified for ISO 9001 and ISO 14001 standards. 
a) Accidental release prevention and emergency response policies at the stationary source - The accidental release prevention policy at the Edison site is documented in the Management System. It includes all the required elements of RMP including maintaining Process Safety Information, Employee participation, Process Hazard Analysis, Standard Operating Procedures, EHS Operator Training, Pre-Startup Review, a Mechanical Integrity Program, Hot Work Permit program, Management of Change Program, EHS Accident Investigation, Emergency Response Plan, Compliance audits, and IST review program. The Edison Site strives to maintain a safe working environment, it is therefore essential that employees be able to deal effectively with emergencies that may develop during the course of operations. Therefore, a multi-functional emergency response team has been formed. The Site Emergency Response Team shall provide the actions necessary to control an emergency with the following priorities:1. To safeguard the lives of company personnel;2. To protect the wellbeing of our visitors, contractors, truck drivers, neighbors and the community;3. To protect the environment;4. To protect company property. The areas of responsibility include:1. Fire control;2. Hazardous materials response;3. First aid;4. Search and rescue;5. Confined space rescue;6. Trench collapse rescue;7. Evacuation;8. Security;9. Weapons of Mass Destruction/Terrorism response;10. Community relations. It is the Edison Sites policy to cooperate fully with Local, State and Federal agencies to mitigate any emergency while protecting the well-being of our employees, neighbors, and the environment. Therefore, emergency response organizations shall be provided wit

h a current issue of the emergency response plan and are invited to participate in annual emergency response exercises. Safety Data Sheets (SDS) for all hazardous materials stored on site are available to both site personnel and Edison Township emergency responders through our Hazard Communication Program. 
b) The stationary source and regulated substances handled - The facility is covered by EPA-RMP regulations due to the presence of Titanium Tetrachloride.
c) The general accidental release prevention program and chemical specific prevention steps - Site release prevention and chemical specific prevention includes process safety equipment, mitigation systems, and leak detection equipment, including a preventative maintenance program covering such equipment, an operator training program, and a Management of Change procedure. Process safety equipment at the Edison Site includes relief devices such as relief valves and rupture disks, vents, check valves, quench systems, automatic shutoffs, interlocks, keyed bypasses, grounding and purge systems. Mitigation systems in the accidental release prevention program include, enclosures, scrubbers, dikes, sumps, sprinkler systems, deluge systems, water curtains, a hazmat foam system, firefighting foam systems, mineral oil dump systems, neutralization and fire water containment system. Leak detection systems are installed in process areas to detect toxic or flammable leaks and oxygen deficient environments. The preventative maintenance program conducts inspections and tests to assure the operation of preventive devices. Management of Change assures that all changes are reviewed for their hazards before implementation and considers the need for process safety equipment, mitigation equipment, and leak detection systems. All incidents are investigated to determine the root cause and corrective actions are implemented to prevent future incidents.
d) In the last five years, the Edison site has had one major accident, in which 660 lb

s. of titanium tetrachloride were released. The event occurred in August of 2020, and a shelter in place was ordered, with no deaths or injuries occurring as a result of the release. The initiating cause of the event was an equipment failure allowing for unintended reaction.
e) The site emergency response program meets the requirements of the EPA Integrated Contingency Plan Guidance. The plan defines the response organization, coordination with the local emergency response committee, equipment, response procedures, training, notification procedures, and drills. The plan is updated according to the recommendations from the system deficiencies uncovered by periodic drills and incident reports.
f) Planned changes to improve safety  To improve the emergency response capabilities of the site, operations and other select personnel have received enhanced emergency response trainings, including basic fire brigade, hazmat, confined space rescue, and CPR/first aid/AED training. New operating buildings on the site have been built with safety features including foam suppression and water curtains. A new quick attack response vehicle is planned to be added to the site to further increase the on-site response capability.
